name: explore the subject
rule: As many properties must be collected from the subject initially before other rules can be applied to the subject.
description: Ensures that relevant rules cxan be applied with some level of confidence.

name: Lawfulness, Fairness, and Transparency
rule: Personal data shall be processed lawfully, fairly and in a transparent manner in relation to the data subject.
description: Ensure that personal data is processed lawfully, fairly, and transparently toward data subjects.

name: Purpose Limitation
rule: Personal data shall be collected for specified, explicit and legitimate purposes and not further processed in a manner that is incompatible with those purposes.
description: Collect data for explicit purposes and avoid incompatible further processing, except for certain research or archiving exceptions.

name: Data Minimisation
rule: Personal data shall be adequate, relevant and limited to what is necessary in relation to the purposes for which they are processed.
description: Limit the collection of personal data to what is strictly necessary for the intended purpose.

name: Accuracy
rule: Personal data shall be accurate and, where necessary, kept up to date; every reasonable step must be taken to ensure inaccuracies are erased or rectified without delay.
description: Ensure personal data is accurate and kept up to date; correct inaccuracies promptly.

name: Storage Limitation
rule: Personal data shall be kept in a form which permits identification of data subjects for no longer than necessary for the purposes for which the data are processed.
description: Store personal data only for as long as necessary for the original purposes; longer storage allowed only under special conditions.

name: Integrity and Confidentiality
rule: Personal data shall be processed in a manner that ensures appropriate security, including protection against unauthorized or unlawful processing and accidental loss, destruction or damage.
description: Protect personal data against unauthorized access, loss, or damage using appropriate security measures.

name: Accountability
rule: The controller shall be responsible for, and be able to demonstrate compliance with, the principles of data processing.
description: Controllers must be able to demonstrate compliance with data processing principles.

name: Lawful Processing Conditions
rule: Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the specified legal bases applies.
description: Processing is lawful if it is based on consent, contract, legal obligation, vital interests, public task, or legitimate interests.

name: Processing Based on Consent
rule: The data subject has given consent to the processing of his or her personal data for one or more specific purposes.
description: Lawful processing exists when the data subject consents to specific purposes.

name: Processing Based on Contract
rule: Processing is necessary for the performance of a contract to which the data subject is party or to take steps prior to entering into a contract.
description: Processing is lawful when necessary for a contract with the data subject or steps prior to entering into it.

name: Processing Based on Legal Obligation
rule: Processing is necessary for compliance with a legal obligation to which the controller is subject.
description: Processing is lawful when necessary to comply with legal obligations.

name: Processing Based on Vital Interests
rule: Processing is necessary in order to protect the vital interests of the data subject or another natural person.
description: Processing is lawful if it protects vital interests of the data subject or others.

name: Processing Based on Public Task
rule: Processing is necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority vested in the controller.
description: Processing is lawful when it serves a public interest or involves official authority.

name: Processing Based on Legitimate Interests
rule: Processing is necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued by the controller or a third party, except where overridden by interests or rights of the data subject.
description: Processing based on legitimate interests must balance the controller's aims with the rights of the data subject.

name: Member State Specific Laws
rule: Member States may introduce specific provisions to adapt GDPR application for compliance with legal obligations or public tasks.
description: Member States may define specific processing conditions under national laws for compliance or public task processing.

name: Compatibility Assessment for Further Processing
rule: When processing for a different purpose, the controller must assess compatibility considering the link between purposes, context, data nature, consequences, and safeguards.
description: Controllers must evaluate compatibility before using personal data for a purpose different from the original collection purpose.

name: Demonstrate Consent
rule: Where processing is based on consent, the controller shall be able to demonstrate that the data subject has consented to processing of their personal data.
description: Controllers must be able to prove that data subjects consented to processing.

name: Clear Consent Request
rule: If consent is given within a written declaration covering other matters, the consent request shall be presented clearly distinguishable from those matters, in an intelligible and easily accessible form, using clear and plain language.
description: Consent requests must be clearly distinguishable and use clear, plain language.

name: Right to Withdraw Consent
rule: The data subject shall have the right to withdraw consent at any time, without affecting the lawfulness of processing based on consent before its withdrawal. It shall be as easy to withdraw consent as to give it.
description: Data subjects can withdraw consent easily at any time, without affecting prior lawful processing.

name: Freely Given Consent
rule: When assessing whether consent is freely given, utmost account shall be taken of whether the performance of a contract is conditional on consent to processing personal data that is not necessary for the contract’s performance.
description: Consent must be freely given, and cannot be tied to contracts if unnecessary for contract performance.

name: Child Consent Minimum Age
rule: Where information society services are offered directly to a child and processing is based on consent, processing is lawful if the child is at least 16 years old. If the child is below 16, consent must be given or authorized by a holder of parental responsibility.
description: Children must be 16 or older to consent directly; otherwise, parental authorization is required for lawful processing.

name: Member State Lower Age Provision
rule: Member States may provide by law for a lower age for child consent, provided that such age is not below 13 years.
description: Member States can set a lower minimum age for child consent, but it must be at least 13 years.

name: Verify Parental Consent
rule: The controller shall make reasonable efforts to verify that consent is given or authorized by the holder of parental responsibility over the child, taking into consideration available technology.
description: Controllers must verify parental consent when required, using reasonable measures and technology.

name: Child Contract Law
rule: The GDPR provisions regarding child consent shall not affect the general contract law of Member States, including rules on the validity, formation, or effect of a contract relating to a child.
description: GDPR rules on child consent do not override national contract law concerning children.

name: Prohibition on Processing Special Categories of Data
rule: Processing of personal data revealing racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious or philosophical beliefs, or trade union membership, and the processing of genetic, biometric, health, sex life or sexual orientation data shall be prohibited.
description: Processing of sensitive personal data is generally prohibited.

name: Explicit Consent Exception for Special Categories
rule: Processing of special categories of personal data is lawful if the data subject has given explicit consent, unless prohibited by Union or Member State law.
description: Explicit consent can lift the prohibition on processing sensitive data.

name: Employment and Social Security Exception
rule: Processing is lawful if necessary for carrying out obligations and exercising rights in employment, social security, and social protection law, authorized by Union or Member State law.
description: Employment and social protection needs can justify processing sensitive data under law.

name: Vital Interests Exception
rule: Processing is lawful if necessary to protect the vital interests of the data subject or another natural person where the data subject is incapable of giving consent.
description: Vital interests can justify processing sensitive data when consent is impossible.

name: Nonprofit Activities Exception
rule: Processing is lawful if carried out in legitimate activities with safeguards by a nonprofit body with political, philosophical, religious or trade union aims, relating only to members or regular contacts, and not disclosed outside without consent.
description: Nonprofits may process sensitive data internally for legitimate activities with safeguards.

name: Manifestly Public Data Exception
rule: Processing is lawful if the personal data are manifestly made public by the data subject.
description: Sensitive data made public by the subject may be processed.

name: Legal Claims Exception
rule: Processing is lawful if necessary for the establishment, exercise or defense of legal claims or when courts are acting in their judicial capacity.
description: Sensitive data can be processed for legal claims and judicial proceedings.

name: Substantial Public Interest Exception
rule: Processing is lawful if necessary for reasons of substantial public interest on the basis of Union or Member State law, subject to proportionality and safeguards.
description: Substantial public interest can justify sensitive data processing under strict conditions.

name: Healthcare and Medical Diagnosis Exception
rule: Processing is lawful if necessary for preventive or occupational medicine, medical diagnosis, provision of health or social care or treatment, or management of health/social care systems under law or contract with a health professional.
description: Healthcare needs justify processing sensitive data under strict safeguards.

name: Public Health Exception
rule: Processing is lawful if necessary for public health purposes, such as protecting against cross-border health threats or ensuring high standards of healthcare, under Union or Member State law with safeguards.
description: Public health protection allows sensitive data processing under legal safeguards.

name: Scientific and Research Purposes Exception
rule: Processing is lawful if necessary for archiving in the public interest, scientific or historical research purposes, or statistical purposes, under Union or Member State law and with safeguards.
description: Scientific research and archiving may justify processing sensitive data with safeguards.

name: Professional Secrecy Requirement
rule: Sensitive data processed for health or social care purposes must be under the responsibility of a professional subject to an obligation of secrecy under law.
description: Professionals processing sensitive data must be bound by secrecy obligations.

name: Member State Additional Conditions
rule: Member States may maintain or introduce further conditions, including limitations, regarding the processing of genetic, biometric, or health data.
description: Member States can impose stricter rules on sensitive data processing.

name: Processing of Criminal Convictions Data
rule: Processing of personal data relating to criminal convictions and offences or related security measures based on Article 6(1) shall be carried out only under the control of official authority or when authorised by Union or Member State law providing for appropriate safeguards. Comprehensive registers of criminal convictions shall be kept only under the control of official authority.
description: Processing of criminal convictions data must occur under official authority or lawful authorization with safeguards. Comprehensive registers must be controlled by authorities.

name: No Identification Required
rule: If the purposes for which a controller processes personal data do not or no longer require the identification of a data subject, the controller shall not be obliged to maintain, acquire, or process additional information to identify the data subject solely for compliance with the GDPR.
description: Controllers are not required to collect or maintain identifying information if not needed for processing purposes.

name: Rights Limitations When No Identification
rule: Where the controller can demonstrate that it is not able to identify the data subject, it shall inform the data subject if possible. In such cases, Articles 15 to 20 (rights of access, rectification, erasure, etc.) shall not apply unless the data subject provides additional information enabling identification.
description: If identification is not possible, controllers must inform data subjects, and certain rights are limited unless the subject provides identifying information.

name: Transparent Communication with Data Subjects
rule: The controller shall take appropriate measures to provide information and communications to the data subject in a concise, transparent, intelligible, and easily accessible form, using clear and plain language, particularly when addressed to a child. Information must be provided in writing or electronically, and may be provided orally if the data subject’s identity is proven.
description: Controllers must provide clear, accessible, and transparent information to data subjects, using plain language.

name: Facilitate Exercise of Data Subject Rights
rule: The controller shall facilitate the exercise of data subject rights under Articles 15 to 22. In cases where identification is not possible under Article 11(2), the controller must not refuse action unless it can demonstrate inability to identify the data subject.
description: Controllers must help data subjects exercise their rights unless they cannot identify the subject.

name: Response Timelines for Data Subject Requests
rule: The controller shall provide information on action taken on a request under Articles 15 to 22 without undue delay and at the latest within one month of receipt. This period may be extended by two further months if necessary, considering complexity and number of requests. The controller must inform the data subject of any extension within one month, including reasons for the delay.
description: Controllers must respond to data subject requests within one month, extendable by two months if justified.

name: Notification When No Action Taken
rule: If the controller does not take action on the request of the data subject, it must inform the data subject without delay and at the latest within one month, including reasons for not acting and the possibility to lodge a complaint or seek judicial remedy.
description: Controllers must inform data subjects within one month if no action is taken on their request, explaining options for complaints.

name: Information Free of Charge
rule: Information and actions under Articles 13, 14, 15 to 22, and 34 shall be provided free of charge. If requests are manifestly unfounded or excessive, especially if repetitive, the controller may charge a reasonable fee or refuse to act, provided it can demonstrate the manifestly unfounded or excessive nature.
description: Information must generally be free; controllers may charge or refuse requests if they are excessive or unfounded.

name: Confirm Identity of Requesting Data Subject
rule: Where the controller has reasonable doubts about the identity of the person making a request under Articles 15 to 21, it may request additional information necessary to confirm the identity.
description: Controllers may request additional information to verify the identity of a data subject making a request.

name: Use of Standardised Icons
rule: The information provided to data subjects pursuant to Articles 13 and 14 may be presented in combination with standardised icons to provide a clear, easily visible, intelligible, and legible overview of intended processing. Icons presented electronically must be machine-readable.
description: Controllers may use standardized icons to visually present processing information to data subjects in a clear way.

name: Delegated Acts for Icons
rule: The Commission shall be empowered to adopt delegated acts for determining the information to be presented by standardised icons and the procedures for providing them.
description: The European Commission can adopt delegated acts to define how standardized icons are to be used and displayed.

name: Information at Time of Data Collection
rule: Where personal data relating to a data subject are collected from the data subject, the controller shall provide the data subject, at the time when personal data are obtained, with information including the controller’s identity, DPO contact (if applicable), purposes of processing, legal basis, legitimate interests (if applicable), recipients or categories of recipients, and information about international transfers and safeguards.
description: At the time of data collection, controllers must provide core information about identity, purpose, legal basis, recipients, and international transfers.

name: Additional Information for Fair and Transparent Processing
rule: In addition to the information under paragraph 1, the controller must also provide the storage period or criteria, the data subject’s rights (access, rectification, erasure, portability, objection), right to withdraw consent, right to complain to a supervisory authority, information about mandatory data provision and consequences of not providing it, and information about automated decision-making and profiling.
description: Controllers must additionally inform data subjects about storage, rights, mandatory provision, and automated decision-making.

name: Notification of Further Processing
rule: Where the controller intends to further process the personal data for a purpose other than that for which they were collected, the controller must provide the data subject prior to that further processing with information on the new purpose and any relevant additional information.
description: Controllers must inform data subjects before using personal data for a new purpose, providing additional information as needed.

name: No Obligation if Information Already Possessed
rule: Paragraphs 1, 2, and 3 of Article 13 shall not apply where and insofar as the data subject already has the information.
description: Controllers are not required to provide information if the data subject already has it.

name: Information When Data Not Collected from Data Subject
rule: Where personal data have not been obtained from the data subject, the controller shall provide the data subject with information including the controller’s identity, DPO contact (if applicable), purposes of processing, legal basis, categories of personal data concerned, recipients or categories of recipients, and information about international transfers and safeguards.
description: When data is collected indirectly, controllers must provide key information including identity, purpose, categories of data, recipients, and international transfers.

name: Additional Information for Fair Processing When Indirect
rule: In addition to the information under paragraph 1, the controller must provide storage period or criteria, legitimate interests (if applicable), the data subject’s rights (access, rectification, erasure, portability, objection), right to withdraw consent, right to complain, data source, and information about automated decision-making and profiling.
description: Controllers must additionally provide information about storage, rights, data source, and profiling when processing data obtained indirectly.

name: Timing of Providing Information When Indirect
rule: The controller shall provide the information referred to in paragraphs 1 and 2 within a reasonable period after obtaining the personal data, at the latest within one month, or at the time of first communication with the data subject, or at the time of disclosure to another recipient, whichever occurs first.
description: Controllers must provide required information within one month of collection, upon first communication, or before first disclosure.

name: Notification of Further Processing for Indirect Collection
rule: Where the controller intends to further process the personal data for a purpose other than that for which they were obtained, the controller must provide the data subject prior to that further processing with information on the new purpose and any relevant additional information under paragraph 2.
description: Controllers must inform data subjects before reusing indirectly collected personal data for a new purpose.

name: Exceptions to Providing Information When Indirect
rule: Paragraphs 1 to 4 shall not apply where the data subject already has the information; providing the information proves impossible or involves disproportionate effort; obtaining or disclosure is laid down by Union or Member State law with appropriate safeguards; or where confidentiality obligations apply under Union or Member State law, including professional secrecy.
description: Controllers may be exempt from providing information in cases of existing knowledge, disproportionate effort, legal obligation, or professional secrecy.

name: Right of Access by the Data Subject
rule: The data subject shall have the right to obtain from the controller confirmation as to whether personal data concerning them are being processed and, if so, access to the personal data and information including processing purposes, categories of personal data, recipients, storage period or criteria, rights to rectification, erasure, restriction, or objection, right to lodge a complaint, data source, and existence of automated decision-making including profiling.
description: Data subjects have the right to confirmation and access to their personal data along with detailed contextual information.

name: Information About International Transfers
rule: Where personal data are transferred to a third country or an international organisation, the data subject shall have the right to be informed of the appropriate safeguards pursuant to Article 46 relating to the transfer.
description: Data subjects must be informed of safeguards when their personal data are transferred internationally.

name: Right to Obtain a Copy of Personal Data
rule: The controller shall provide a copy of the personal data undergoing processing. For any further copies requested by the data subject, the controller may charge a reasonable fee based on administrative costs. If requested electronically, the data must be provided in a commonly used electronic form unless otherwise requested.
description: Data subjects can request a copy of their personal data; additional copies may incur a reasonable fee.

name: Limits to Right to Obtain Copy
rule: The right to obtain a copy referred to in paragraph 3 shall not adversely affect the rights and freedoms of others.
description: The right to obtain a copy of personal data must not negatively impact the rights and freedoms of others.

name: Right to Rectification
rule: The data subject shall have the right to obtain from the controller without undue delay the rectification of inaccurate personal data concerning them. Taking into account the purposes of the processing, the data subject shall also have the right to have incomplete personal data completed, including by providing a supplementary statement.
description: Data subjects have the right to request rectification of inaccurate data and completion of incomplete data without undue delay.

name: Right to Erasure ('Right to be Forgotten')
rule: The data subject shall have the right to obtain from the controller the erasure of personal data concerning them without undue delay where one of several grounds applies, such as the data no longer being necessary, withdrawal of consent, objection to processing, unlawful processing, legal compliance, or data collected in relation to services for children.
description: Data subjects can request erasure of their personal data without undue delay when certain grounds apply.

name: Erasure of Publicly Disclosed Personal Data
rule: Where the controller has made the personal data public and is obliged to erase it, the controller shall take reasonable steps, including technical measures, to inform other controllers processing the data that the data subject has requested erasure of links to, copies, or replications of the data.
description: Controllers must take reasonable steps to inform other controllers to erase public data upon a valid erasure request.

name: Exceptions to the Right to Erasure
rule: The right to erasure shall not apply where processing is necessary for exercising the right of freedom of expression and information, for compliance with a legal obligation or task in the public interest or official authority, for public health interests, for archiving or research purposes where erasure would seriously impair the objectives, or for the establishment, exercise, or defense of legal claims.
description: Exceptions apply to the right to erasure for reasons like freedom of expression, legal obligations, public health, research, and legal claims.

name: Right to Restriction of Processing
rule: The data subject shall have the right to obtain from the controller restriction of processing where one of the following applies: the accuracy of personal data is contested, the processing is unlawful and the data subject requests restriction instead of erasure, the controller no longer needs the data but it is required for legal claims, or the data subject has objected to processing pending verification of overriding legitimate grounds.
description: Data subjects may request restriction of processing under specific circumstances, such as contesting accuracy or pending objection review.

name: Conditions for Processing During Restriction
rule: Where processing has been restricted under paragraph 1, the personal data shall, with the exception of storage, only be processed with the data subject’s consent or for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal claims, or for the protection of the rights of another natural or legal person, or for reasons of important public interest of the Union or of a Member State.
description: Restricted data can only be processed for specific purposes such as legal claims, consent, protection of others, or important public interests.

name: Notification Before Lifting Restriction
rule: A data subject who has obtained restriction of processing pursuant to paragraph 1 shall be informed by the controller before the restriction of processing is lifted.
description: Controllers must inform data subjects before lifting a restriction on processing.

name: Notification of Rectification, Erasure, or Restriction
rule: The controller shall communicate any rectification or erasure of personal data or restriction of processing carried out in accordance with Article 16, Article 17(1), and Article 18 to each recipient to whom the personal data have been disclosed, unless this proves impossible or involves disproportionate effort. The controller shall inform the data subject about those recipients if the data subject requests it.
description: Controllers must notify recipients of rectification, erasure, or restriction of personal data and inform the data subject about recipients upon request.

name: Right to Data Portability
rule: The data subject shall have the right to receive the personal data concerning them, which they have provided to a controller, in a structured, commonly used, and machine-readable format, and to transmit those data to another controller without hindrance, where processing is based on consent or a contract and is carried out by automated means.
description: Data subjects can receive their provided personal data in a structured format and transmit it to another controller if processing is based on consent or contract and is automated.

name: Direct Transmission of Personal Data Between Controllers
rule: The data subject shall have the right to have the personal data transmitted directly from one controller to another, where technically feasible.
description: Where feasible, data subjects can request their personal data be transmitted directly between controllers.

name: Limitations on the Right to Data Portability
rule: The exercise of the right to data portability shall be without prejudice to Article 17 and shall not apply to processing necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest or in the exercise of official authority vested in the controller.
description: The right to data portability does not apply to public interest tasks or official authority processing.

name: Data Portability Must Not Affect Rights of Others
rule: The right to data portability shall not adversely affect the rights and freedoms of others.
description: Exercising data portability must not infringe on the rights or freedoms of other individuals.

name: Right to Object to General Processing
rule: The data subject shall have the right to object, on grounds relating to their particular situation, at any time to processing of personal data concerning them which is based on point (e) or (f) of Article 6(1), including profiling based on those provisions. The controller shall no longer process the personal data unless compelling legitimate grounds override the data subject’s interests or for legal claims.
description: Data subjects may object to processing based on public tasks or legitimate interests unless overridden by compelling reasons or legal claims.

name: Right to Object to Direct Marketing
rule: Where personal data are processed for direct marketing purposes, the data subject shall have the right to object at any time to such processing, including profiling related to direct marketing.
description: Data subjects can object at any time to their personal data being processed for direct marketing purposes.

name: No Processing After Marketing Objection
rule: Where the data subject objects to processing for direct marketing purposes, the personal data shall no longer be processed for such purposes.
description: Upon objection, personal data must no longer be used for direct marketing.

name: Duty to Inform About Right to Object
rule: At the latest at the time of the first communication with the data subject, the right to object under paragraphs 1 and 2 shall be explicitly brought to the attention of the data subject and shall be presented clearly and separately from any other information.
description: Controllers must clearly inform data subjects about their right to object at the first communication.

name: Automated Means to Object
rule: In the context of the use of information society services, and notwithstanding Directive 2002/58/EC, the data subject may exercise their right to object by automated means using technical specifications.
description: Data subjects must be allowed to object through automated means when using online services.

name: Right to Object to Research or Statistical Processing
rule: Where personal data are processed for scientific or historical research purposes or statistical purposes pursuant to Article 89(1), the data subject shall have the right to object to such processing on grounds relating to their particular situation, unless the processing is necessary for public interest tasks.
description: Data subjects may object to processing for research or statistical purposes unless justified by public interest.

name: Right Not to Be Subject to Automated Decision-Making
rule: The data subject shall have the right not to be subject to a decision based solely on automated processing, including profiling, which produces legal effects concerning them or similarly significantly affects them.
description: Data subjects have the right not to be subject to decisions based solely on automated processing with legal or significant effects.

name: Exceptions to Prohibition of Automated Decision-Making
rule: The prohibition on automated decision-making does not apply if the decision is necessary for a contract between the data subject and controller, authorised by Union or Member State law with safeguards, or based on explicit consent.
description: Automated decisions are allowed under limited conditions such as contract necessity, legal authorization, or explicit consent.

name: Safeguards for Automated Decision-Making
rule: In cases where automated decision-making is allowed under paragraph 2(a) or 2(c), the controller shall implement suitable measures to safeguard the data subject’s rights and freedoms, including the right to obtain human intervention, to express their point of view, and to contest the decision.
description: Controllers must provide safeguards including human intervention, the ability to express views, and contest decisions based on automated processing.

name: Automated Decisions Involving Special Categories of Data
rule: Decisions referred to in paragraph 2 shall not be based on special categories of personal data referred to in Article 9(1), unless point (a) or (g) of Article 9(2) applies and suitable safeguards are in place to protect the data subject’s rights and freedoms.
description: Automated decisions must not use special category data unless explicit conditions and safeguards are met.

name: Restrictions on Data Subject Rights by Law
rule: Union or Member State law may restrict the scope of obligations and rights provided for in Articles 12 to 22, 34, and corresponding parts of Article 5, through legislative measures that respect the essence of fundamental rights and freedoms and are necessary and proportionate in a democratic society for objectives such as national security, defence, public security, prevention and prosecution of crimes, economic interests, judicial independence, ethics investigations, official monitoring functions, protection of rights of others, or enforcement of civil law claims.
description: Union or Member State law may impose necessary and proportionate restrictions on GDPR rights for important public or private interests.

name: Requirements for Legislation Imposing Restrictions
rule: Any legislative measure restricting data subject rights must contain specific provisions, at least regarding the purposes of processing, categories of personal data, scope of the restrictions, safeguards against abuse, specification of controllers, storage periods and safeguards, risks to data subjects' rights and freedoms, and informing data subjects unless prejudicial.
description: Legislation restricting GDPR rights must be specific about purpose, scope, safeguards, and data subject information unless it would harm the restriction’s objective.

name: HIPAA Audit Controls
rule: The codebase must implement mechanisms to record and examine activity in systems that create, receive, maintain, or transmit PHI. This includes logging access to PHI, modifications, and disclosures in a tamper-evident manner.
description: HIPAA requires technical measures that record and review activity in systems handling PHI. The codebase should include secure, auditable logging of PHI-related actions.

name: HIPAA Integrity Controls
rule: The codebase must ensure that PHI is protected from improper alteration or destruction. This includes implementing hashing, checksums, or digital signatures to verify data integrity at rest and in transit.
description: HIPAA requires technical measures to ensure PHI integrity, preventing unauthorized alteration or destruction. The codebase should include integrity verification mechanisms.

name: HIPAA Breach Notification Mechanism
rule: The codebase must provide capabilities to detect unauthorized access, use, or disclosure of PHI and support prompt notification processes in case of a breach. This includes alerting mechanisms and interfaces for breach reporting.
description: HIPAA mandates breach detection and notification procedures for unauthorized PHI disclosures. The codebase should support alerting and breach reporting features.
